The cry of an innocent child rises and falls like the distant echo of a forgotten conscience, a haunting reminder of a world that once held promise and purity.  In the laughter of children lies the fragile hope of humanity, a hope untainted by the divisions or ideologies that the wicked have twisted into instruments of pain.   Yet here they stand‚Äîbewildered, defenseless‚Äîcaught in the suffocating grasp of a hatred they can neither name nor comprehend.  What kind of civilization looks upon the loss of innocence and turns its gaze away?
   We pride ourselves on progress.  Over the course of millennia, we have crafted laws and woven complex philosophies meant to elevate us above the barbarism of our forebears.  We have charted the stars, unlocked the secrets of nature, and crafted towering monuments that defy the passage of time.   But what value do these achievements hold if we cannot protect the innocence of a child?   If all our supposed advancements lead only to the same tragic outcome‚Äîthe silencing of the young and pure‚Äîthen we must ask ourselves: what does it mean to be civilized?  How can we celebrate progress when we remain powerless to shield those least equipped to defend themselves?
   We bury the truth beneath layers of rhetoric, muttering phrases like ‚Äúcollateral damage‚Äù as if those words could dull such painful loss.  The architects of war perform a deft trick, casting spells with words that drain human suffering of its weight, disguising horror as a mere consequence of policy.  But strip away the illusion, look beneath the mask, and what remains is the same raw truth: there is no justification for the blood of a child to stain the soil of any nation.  The cost is too great, yet language has found a way to cloak the unacceptable, making it seem bearable.
   Imagine a world where the guiding principle of every decision was the gaze of a child‚Äîtheir innocent, questioning eyes.  Could we still hide behind strategies and doctrines then?   Would we still feign blindness to the cost if every casualty were viewed through that single, unflinching lens?  If this were our measure of civilization, how many could stand without shame?  
   The gravest threat we face is not war itself, but the leaders who diminish a child‚Äôs death into an abstraction.  They wield their words with surgical precision, dissecting morality until nothing remains but the cold calculus of bureaucracy.  And we accept it‚Äîbecause confronting the depth of our own complicity is unbearable.  We avert our eyes, whispering, ‚ÄúWhat can be done?‚Äù as if the truth itself were too heavy to bear.
   But what if we refused to accept this narrative?  What if we cast aside the veil of apathy and reimagined a world shaped not by force, but by the courage of those who will no longer tolerate veiled words and hollow justifications?  This is not mere idealism‚Äîit is the only progress worthy of the name.  It is the only achievement that would earn us the right to call ourselves truly civilized.
   To call a child‚Äôs death anything less than a tragedy, to dismiss it as an unfortunate side effect of some grander scheme, is to sever ourselves from our own humanity.  It is to speak a language that betrays our deepest values, denying the truth that lives within every human heart.  And yet, how easily we become fluent in these hollow phrases, how willingly we let ourselves be ensnared by them.
   What is the answer?  It begins with daring to redefine what truly matters.  To judge our progress not by the magnitude of our achievements, but by the gentleness with which we tread upon the earth.  To measure success not by power or wealth, but by how fiercely we guard the sanctity of life‚Äîespecially the lives of those too young to understand why the world is as it is.
   We stand at a crossroads, our choices heavy with meaning.  Will we let the old spells bind us to the endless cycle of bloodshed, or will we choose a new story‚Äîone where the weeping of a child becomes a clarion call for change?  For in the end, it is not what we build or destroy that will define us.  It is how we choose to see, how we choose to speak, and whether we have the courage to break the silence that permits the suffering of the innocent.
   If we dare to reject the narratives that justify and obscure, if we dare to speak the unadorned truth, then perhaps‚Äîjust perhaps‚Äîwe can begin to emerge from the long shadow of our past.  Only then will we have earned the right to call ourselves truly civilized.

So, I've watched this video in full. 

I think the actions of the Israel Defense Forces are disgusting. And I think Al Jazeera has done good coverage of their crimes.

However, critiques I have for this is that this video is titled "war crimes in Gaza." Yet, in reality, this is only about Israeli war crimes, and it seems to whitewash the complicity of Hamas in this war. October 7, for example, was only given two minutes of time in this video. You certainly did good coverage of Israeli civilians celebrating war crimes. However, where is the coverage of Palestinians praising October 7? While I do understand the brutality of October 7 (primarily the events at Re'im and Kfar Aza) were reported to death by other media news sources, this does not excuse that the event should be reverted to a mere footnote, because there are also a lot of stories untold on that terrible day just like the many stories coming out of the Gaza Strip. Entire families were burned alive. Women and children were not spared. Babies were shot in their cribs at point-blank range, some other civilians beheaded, war crimes which I still have yet to see the IDF ever doing. While it is troubling the IDF is salivating at the sight of cultural genocide and urbicide, it's still a stark contrast to Hamas that has salivated at having a front-row seat to human pain and suffering, not even showing babies mercy at point-blank range. And I've seen Palestinian journalists, academics and activists either downplay October 7 or even endorse what happened on that atrocious day. Refaat Alareer, for example, is a slain professor from the Islamic University of Gaza that has been celebrated as this humble saint on Al Jazeera and Palestinian social media - yet know one talks about his dark sides, that he made fun of the families of hostages, called all Israeli civilians complicit in the occupation thus can't be civilians, and cursed out world leaders who called hostage-taking a war crime. In other words, it takes two to tango. Both sides have deep hatred for the other to the point of derangement. Many try to excuse the Palestinians for their extremism because they argue that it is a product of Israeli occupation. To that, I cry bullshit. 

Palestinians cannot claim to be against genocide, mutilation, humiliation, and human rights violations only when it happens to them. In order to have a moral high ground, it's not enough to just be the weaker or occupied side in a conflict. You need to show contrast to your enemy. When Ukraine entered Russia's Kursk Oblast, for example, they didn't come into Sudzha and rape and kill as many civilians as they possibly could, all in spite of the fact that Russia does that to Ukrainian civilians all the time. People say that Westerners support Ukraine, but not Palestine, because of racial bias. Maybe there might be a nugget of truth to that, but it's also simplistic. Because let's be honest: it's a lot easier to support Ukraine. Unlike Palestine who wants to wipe Israel off the map, Ukraine doesn't want to wipe Russia off the map. Unlike Hamas who tortures and mutilates civilians, Ukraine is merciful toward Russian civilians it occupies. Now many people I've talked to will try to say, "Well, what about uMkhonto we Sizwe that was led by Nelson Mandela in South Africa, which at times targeted civilians to fight apartheid?" First of all, while that is true, it's different. You see, Mandela himself even admitted that it was tragic whenever it devolved into civilian targets. But Hamas celebrates it, and so does their supporters. Also, I dispute the notion that the ANC had to target civilians to end apartheid in general. I would say that was a flaw of the movement, not one of its strengths. 

Trying to absolve Hamas of the human shield allegations is a bit dishonest. While I can agree that Israel does use the human shield argument as plausible deniability for their war crimes, that absolutely does not mean Hamas isn't complicit in using human shields. There was very little mention of the fact Hamas has a tunnel network all across the Gaza Strip, which transcend underneath hospitals and civilian areas. Hamas may not operate within civilian buildings all the time, but they do use tunnel networks and bunkers underneath them constantly. And let's also remember that a common used talking point on the Palestinian side is that, unlike the Israelis, Palestinians do not have bomb shelters. Actually, they do. The problem is, those shelters are exclusive to Hamas. Instead of doing the opposite, which is sheltering civilians underground and having militants fight above ground, they are sheltering underneath the civilians. Why did you not address that part of the story? 

I'm so tired of neither side wanting to tell the full story. As I said before, it takes two to tango. Both sides have serious issues they need to sort out.

The brutal attack of October 7th was a searing trauma that unleashed deep-seated fears in the Israeli psyche dating back to the Holocaust. Israelis feel they can neither forgive nor forget. In their eyes, Gaza is no longer just a terrorist haven but a place whose populace is culpable.

By now it should be clear to many that events like October 7 and 9/11 were deliberately allowed to occur by those in power, ultimately to justify subsequent military action given the intelligence gathering capabilities of all parties involved, under the guise of ‚Äújustice.‚Äù Such incidents, while horrific and tragic, provided the pretext for governments to implement sweeping military responses, enabling them to pursue strategic objectives that might otherwise lack public support.

The aftermath of 9/11, for example, led to the War on Terror, extensive military interventions, and a reconfiguration of global alliances and security policies, all framed as necessary for national defence. Similarly, the October 7 attacks have sparked aggressive military operations, drawing on similar narratives of justice and self-defence. These events demonstrate how, in the wake of tragedy, powerful actors often leverage public fear and grief to legitimize actions that expand military and political control, both domestically and abroad.

By framing these responses as morally justified, leaders are able to rally public support and mitigate dissent, allowing them to advance agendas that may include resource control, geopolitical influence, and ideological dominance. Last weekend I woke up to beautiful sunlight and the sounds of birds and wildlife anyone who lives in the Territory knows well.

But I hadn‚Äôt slept well. I couldn‚Äôt.

I was haunted by images of gunmen in my garden, attacking my husband and children while they watched morning TV. I could hear screaming and felt a sense of horror, picturing them turning their weapons towards me.

I was imagining these awful things because I had just arrived home from a visit to Israel, where I visited the Kibbutz that was the site of the Hamas massacre on October 7 last year.

The things I imagined were the things that happened to Israelis in that Kibbutz on that terrible day.

I was shown footage from mobile phones, car dash cams, CCTV and the body-worn cameras of Hamas terrorists.

Footage of things that I will never be able to forget. 

This was a terrorist attack that defies belief and rationality.

These fanatics are not interested in peace or a two-state solution. They want to kill and destroy Jews. That‚Äôs it.

It‚Äôs plain to see, and that leads to the other thing that haunts me.

That here in our Australian cities we had people praising the attacks.

We had marches in the streets about glorifying the ‚Äúmartyrs‚Äù of Hamas.

It didn‚Äôt even take people ‚Äì including left-wing activists in the Greens ‚Äì 48 hours after October 7 to start protesting against Israel, who had just had over a thousand of their citizens murdered.

It‚Äôs astonishing and, dare I say it, scary for that to happen on our own shores.

Hamas relies on the support of gullible western activists to provide cover for their terror campaigns and there are many in Australia who are only too happy to give it to them.

I‚Äôve written this week in The Australian about my visit to Israel not only to reiterate the evil done against Israel but also to express my disappointment that we‚Äôre still waiting on Prime Minister Albanese to show the leadership we‚Äôve seen from other country‚Äôs leaders and actually visit Israel.

It is time for the Prime Minister to make clear beyond doubt the commitment of Australia to our only democratic partner in the Middle East, to peace in the region and our advocacy for the return of every hostage taken on October 7.

Palestine. Also called: the Holy Land, Canaan the area between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea in which most of the biblical narrative is located. the province of the Roman Empire in this region.  and Its original pre-Israelite inhabitants were called Canaanites. The names Canaan and Canaanite occur in cuneiform, Egyptian, and Phoenician writings from about the 15th century BCE as well as in the Old Testament. In these sources, ‚ÄúCanaan‚Äù refers sometimes to an area encompassing all of Palestine and Syria, sometimes only to the land west of the Jordan River, and sometimes just to a strip of coastal land from Acre ( øAkko) northward. The Israelites occupied and conquered Palestine, or Canaan, beginning in the late 2nd millennium BCE, or perhaps earlier; and the Bible justifies such occupation by identifying Canaan with the Promised Land, the land promised to the Israelites by God.



The origin of the term is disputed, but it may derive from an old Semitic word denoting ‚Äúreddish purple,‚Äù referring to the rich purple or crimson dye produced in the area or to the wool coloured with the dye. Biblically, Canaanites are identified in Genesis as descendants of Canaan, a son of Ham and grandson of Noah. 


The introduction of bronze in the Early Bronze Age (c. 3000‚Äì2000 BCE) brought about a cultural revolution, marked by the development of metallurgy and by a decline in painted pottery. Semitic peoples first appeared in Canaan during this period. With the Middle Bronze Age (c. 2000‚Äìc. 1550 BCE), recorded history in the area began. The Semitic Amorites, who penetrated Canaan from the northeast, became the dominant element of the population during this time. Other invaders included the Egyptians and the Hyksos, a group of Asian peoples who seem to have migrated there from north of Palestine. The Hurrians (the Horites of the Old Testament) also came to Canaan from the north.

The Late Bronze Age (c. 1550‚Äìc. 1200 BCE) was mainly one of Egyptian dominance in Canaan, although their power there was contested by the Hittites of Anatolia. The period was also marked by incursions of marauders called Hapiru, or Habiru (Egyptian:  øApiru). This term was apparently applied by the Egyptians to other peoples or social groups who were of foreign origin. Many scholars feel that among the Hapiru were the original Hebrews, of whom the later Israelites were only one branch or confederation.


By the end of the 13th century BCE, Egypt‚Äôs domination over southern Canaan had waned, and the Hittites collapsed under the assault of enemies from the north. During the transition from the Late Bronze to the Early Iron Age‚Äîprobably about 1250 BCE‚Äîthe Israelites entered Canaan, settling at first in the hill country and in the south. The Israelites‚Äô infiltration was opposed by the Canaanites, who continued to hold the stronger cities of the region. In the following century, Canaan suffered further invasion at the hands of the Philistines, who appear to have come from Crete. They eventually established a coalition of five city-states on the southern coast of Canaan. Under the leadership of King David (10th century BCE), the Israelites were finally able to break the Philistine power and at the same time to vanquish the native Canaanites, taking the city of Jerusalem. Thereafter Canaan became, for all practical purposes, the Land of Israel.
(David & Goliath) David a humble young Shepherd who became king after defeating Goliath, a gigantic  Philistinian warrior 



Modern knowledge of Canaan‚Äôs history and culture is derived from both archeological excavations and from literary sources. Excavations, mainly in the 20th century, have unearthed the remains of many important Canaanite cities, including Bet She æan, (‚ÄúGezer‚Äù) which is where I assume the name ‚ÄúGaza‚Äù comes from Hazor, Jericho, Jerusalem, Lachish, Megiddo, and Shechem. The most important literary sources for the region‚Äôs history are the Old Testament; the Ras Shamra texts discovered at the site of ancient Ugarit, on the north coast of Syria; and the Amarna Letters, a set of dispatches sent in the 14th century BCE by governors of Palestinian cities and Syrian cities to their Egyptian overlords.


Canaan was situated at the crossroads of several cultures, and throughout its recorded history its art and literature illustrate a mixture of many elements: Egyptian, Mycenaean, Cretan, Hurrian, and Mesopotamian. Most of what is known about Canaanite religion is derived from a series of tablets discovered at Ras Shamra. The principal god was El, but the jurisdiction over rainfall and fertility was delegated to Baal, or Hadad. Other important deities included Resheph, lord of plague and the nether world; Kothar, the divine craftsman; Asherah, consort of El; and Astarte, goddess of fertility.

The language of the Canaanites may perhaps be best described as an archaic form of Hebrew, standing in much the same relationship to the Hebrew of the Old Testament as does the language of Chaucer to modern English.

I guess it just seems to me that the notion that the deliberate killing of civilians and destruction of civilian property is "out of the norm" and "war crime" seems obtuse. 

We kicked off the modern era with two world wars that were defined by the massive and deliberate targeting of civilians for the express purpose of terrorizing, demoralizing or even annihilating them. WWII in particular. The supposed good guys in that war went all out stacking up German and Japanese civilian bodies. 

And basically every major war since has been that way to varying degrees. Arguably things were a bit more restrained during the US's operations in Korea and Vietnam, and subsequently Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya and Syria ( _arguably_ ) and you could maybe give the Russians some credit for practicing some restraint in their Ukraine invasion (though that's debatable as well).

But I guess my point is - what is this norm? Since when is the deliberate targeting of civilians some exceptionally depraved manner of prosecuting a war?

Maybe centuries ago, before nation states... Back when civilians had value as slaves and subjects I guess. Maybe when Christian chivalry was the norm among warriors. 

But it's been some time that bombing civilians deliberately has been very much on the table in conventional warfare. Pretty much since we developed the technology to drop bombs. 

Not defending Israel or anything - I have little sympathy for that regime - but let's just be honest about how much international "law" against war crimes is actually worth. Not much.

Why Israel helped create Hamas
Since the founding of Hamas in 1987, Israeli, American and Palestinian officials have repeatedly acknowledged that Israel did indeed help create and fund the Islamist group.

The point made by many of these officials is not that Israel ‚Äúallowed‚Äù the rise of Hamas or that Hamas emerged in response to Israeli ‚Äúoccupation‚Äù of Palestine. Rather, their point was and is that Israel‚Äôs intelligence agencies actively helped create and finance the Hamas group.

As the officials cited below make clear, the overall goal of supporting Hamas has been to thwart the creation of a Palestinian state and avert the implementation of a two-state solution to the Palestine question. From Israel‚Äôs perspective, a two-state solution would reduce Israel‚Äôs territory to the internationally recognized pre-1967 borders, prohibit any future territorial expansion, and prevent the recognition of Jerusalem as Israel‚Äôs capital city.

More specifically, supporting the Islamist Hamas group has served several Israeli objectives at once: first, it undermined Yasser Arafat‚Äôs secular nationalist PLO; second, it helped prevent the implementation of the 1993 Oslo Accords; third, it undermined the Palestinian National Authority and isolated Gaza from the Westbank; fourth, it impeded Western support for the Palestinian cause; and fifth, it justified Israeli (counter-)attacks on Palestinian territory.

In other words, by secretly supporting a group that does not recognize the existence of the state of Israel and does not accept a two-state solution, Israel does not have to accept the existence of a Palestinian state and does not have to support a two-state solution, either.

It is sometimes argued that while Israel initially supported the creation of Hamas, the Islamist group got out of control and Israeli officials came to regret their support (the ‚Äúblowback theory‚Äù).

While this is certainly true for some Israeli officials and for the Israeli population affected by Hamas rockets and terrorist attacks, it is not true for Israeli grand strategists, as the quotes below make clear: for them, Hamas has continued to serve its intended purpose even after the Oslo Accords in 1993 and after Israel‚Äôs withdrawal from the Gaza Strip in 2005.

For the grand strategists, the presence of Hamas in the remaining Palestinian territories might provide, one day, the necessary pretext for a ‚Äúfinal solution‚Äù to the Palestinian question.

THERE WAS NO PALESTINIAN STATE
by Imtiaz Mahmood

A little history for those wanting to 'restore Palestine'.

1. Before Israel, there was a British mandate, not a Palestinian state.

2. Before the British Mandate, there was the Ottoman Empire, not a Palestinian state.

3. Before the Ottoman Empire, there was the Islamic state of the Mamluks of Egypt, not a Palestinian state.

4. Before the Islamic state of the Mamluks of Egypt, there was the Ayubid Arab-Kurdish Empire, not a Palestinian state.

5. Before the Ayubid Empire, there was the Frankish and Christian Kingdom of Jerusalem, not a Palestinian state.

6. Before the Kingdom of Jerusalem, there was the Umayyad and Fatimid empires, not a Palestinian state.

7. Before the Umayyad and Fatimid empires, there was the Byzantine Empire, not a Palestinian state.

8. Before the Byzantine Empire, there were the Sassanids, not a Palestinian state.

9. Before the Sassanid Empire, there was the Byzantine Empire, not a Palestinian state.

10. Before the Byzantine Empire, there was the Roman Empire, not a Palestinian state.

11. Before the Roman Empire, there was the Hasmonean state, not a Palestinian state.

12. Before the Hasmonean state, there was the Seleucid, not a Palestinian state.

13. Before the Seleucid empire, there was the empire of Alexander the Great, not a Palestinian state.

14. Before the empire of Alexander the Great, there was the Persian empire, not a Palestinian state.

15. Before the Persian Empire, there was the Babylonian Empire, not a Palestinian state.

16. Before the Babylonian Empire, there were the Kingdoms of Israel and Judah, not a Palestinian state.

17. Before the Kingdoms of Israel and Judah, there was the Kingdom of Israel, not a Palestinian state.

18. Before the kingdom of Israel, there was the theocracy of the twelve tribes of Israel, not a Palestinian state.

19. Before the theocracy of the twelve tribes of Israel, there was an agglomeration of independent Canaanite city-kingdoms, not a Palestinian state.

Actually, in this piece of land, there has been everything, except a Palestinian State.

English Summary (Hosea 9):
Hosea 9 warns of Israel‚Äôs impending punishment for their sins, especially their unfaithfulness to God. The prophet Hosea declares that Israel will go into exile and suffer greatly because they turned to idol worship and abandoned God.

Verses 1-2: Israel should not rejoice like other nations because, despite appearances, their betrayal of God through idolatry will lead to poor harvests and hunger.

Verses 3-4: Israel will be exiled to Assyria, where they will not be able to properly worship God, and their sacrifices will not be pleasing to Him.

Verses 5-6: When Israel is exiled, they will mourn the loss of their homeland. Their grand houses will fall into ruin, and they will die in a foreign land.

Verses 7-9: The time of punishment has come. The prophets and priests who led the people astray are corrupt and unreliable.

Verses 10-13: God remembers how He once loved and protected Israel, but now they have become like rotten fruit. Their sins and betrayal will destroy both them and their children.

Verses 14-17: Hosea pleads with God to punish Israel for their disobedience. They will be left childless and without a future because of their unfaithfulness.

In summary, Hosea 9 emphasizes the consequences of Israel‚Äôs unfaithfulness: they will lose their land, be sent into exile, and suffer the results of their rebellion against God.

Children carry burdens too heavy to hide.
With eyes filled with sorrow, they search for the light,
In a world torn apart by the endless night.

Their laughter is distant, a memory lost,
In the chaos of conflict, they bear the cost.
With dreams turned to whispers, they long to be free,
From the chains of despair that bind them at sea.

Each day is a struggle, each moment a test,
In the ruins of hope, they seek a small rest.
Yet within their small hearts, a flicker remains,
A wish for a future untouched by the chains.

They yearn for a haven where kindness prevails,
Where love is a fortress that never unveils.
In the depths of their trauma, a spirit still glows,
For even in darkness, a seed of hope grows.

Let us hear their silent cries, their hidden plea,
For the souls of these children, let compassion decree.
In the tapestry of life, let peace be the thread,
To mend the broken hearts and heal what is bled.

Heavenly Father, as we nestle in the comforts of our homes, many miles away, lives are being disrupted by the calamities of war. Unfortunately, these innocent lives have been engulfed by the horrors and brutality of war. As they cry out in solitude, waiting for help and clinging to a thin thread of hope, we also join in solidarity by offering our prayers and strength to them. To be united with them, if not physically, then spiritually.

"The Lord is a refuge for the oppressed, a stronghold in times of trouble." (Psalm 9:9)

It is in desperate times like this when the power of prayer is all the more important. For when we gather together in the Lord's name and seek His listening ear, miracles can happen. It is more than mere words, but a powerful offering of solidarity with the victims - those whose lives should never have been touched by the cruel actions that we witness right now in the media.

"He will cover you with his feathers, and under his wings you will find refuge; his faithfulness will be your shield and rampart." (Psalm 91:4)

Let us then, hand in hand, heart with heart, weave a world where no innocent soul feels the chill of war, where every life is sheltered, shielded, and delivered from despair. Father, we offer our prayers and actions in solidarity with the innocent victims of war.May your love and protection encompass them, delivering them from their tribulations. 
In Jesus' name,

Understanding the Psychological Factors Behind the Actions of Hamas Fighters

In the volatile and deeply complex context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, it's crucial to explore the psychological factors that may underlie the actions of individuals who join organizations like Hamas. This draft seeks to understand these underlying causes, particularly focusing on how prolonged exposure to trauma during childhood can manifest in their actions.

1. Complex Trauma: Children growing up in conflict zones often face prolonged exposure to traumatic events. These experiences contribute to what mental health experts describe as complex trauma, which may include violence, loss, and constant insecurity. Such persistent trauma can lead to various psychological symptoms, such as anxiety, depression, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

2. Normalization of Violence: In regions where violence is a daily occurrence, children and adolescents may become desensitized to its effects. The normalization of violence can, in turn, make it more likely for some individuals to resort to violence themselves. For them, violence may serve as a coping mechanism or a way to fight back against perceived oppressors.

3. Loss of Hope: Growing up in a conflict zone can rob children of hope for a better future. They may face barriers to education, opportunities, and essential resources. The loss of hope for a brighter tomorrow can lead some to turn to extremist groups like Hamas as a means of finding purpose and meaning in their lives.

4. Radicalization: The radicalization of individuals, particularly among young people, is primarily attributed to the prolonged occupation of Palestinian territories and the actions of the Israeli State. The constant attacks, restrictions, and the tragic loss of innocent civilians at the hands of occupying forces are significant drivers of radicalization.

The cycle of violence perpetuated by the occupation has a profound impact on the psyche of the Palestinian population. Witnessing their communities, homes, and families affected by ongoing aggression, individuals may feel a growing sense of desperation and powerlessness. As they experience the relentless oppression in their daily lives, it becomes increasingly challenging for them to resist the pull of extremist ideologies.

The environment of oppression and humiliation creates fertile ground for radicalization. Exposure to the harsh realities of occupation, the loss of faith in peaceful resolutions, and the desperate search for a sense of identity and purpose are all amplified by the continuous acts of aggression committed by the Israeli State. For many Palestinians, joining groups like Hamas may be seen as a means of taking a stand against injustice and attempting to regain a sense of control in their lives.

It's important to note that the radicalization of some individuals is a complex issue, and not all Palestinians become radicalized. However, addressing the root causes of this radicalization requires acknowledging the central role that the Israeli occupation and its actions play in this ongoing cycle of violence and extremism. Only by addressing these core issues can we hope to move towards a more peaceful and just resolution.

It is an extremely high standard for death figures, one that certainly results in a figure that is much lower than the real figure.

I gathered some information regarding the available solutions that could have changed the path chosen by Israel and enabled by the west. This can be seen as who are in a position to change their circumstances. The rest can be usefull in countles situations.
1. Dual Citizenship in Israel:
Approximately 10% to 15% of Israeli citizens hold dual citizenship, with a large number having U.S., French, Russian, Canadian, and European nationalities.
Over 1 million Israelis have dual Russian-Israeli citizenship, with significant numbers also holding U.S. (300,000‚Äì500,000), French (150,000‚Äì200,000), and other nationalities.

2. Palestinian Dual Citizenship:
The number of Palestinians with dual citizenship is relatively low, especially in the Gaza Strip. Some Palestinians hold citizenship from countries like the U.S., EU nations, and Jordan (for West Bank residents, but Gaza residents mostly lack full Jordanian citizenship).

3. Palestinian Natural Resources (Oil and Gas):
Palestine has limited oil reserves, mainly in the West Bank, with estimated reserves of around 1.5‚Äì2 million barrels.
More significant are the natural gas reserves in the Gaza Marine gas field, holding around 1 trillion cubic feet (TCF) of natural gas. Development has been stalled due to political instability and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

4. Potential for Economic Development and Independence:
Fully exploiting natural gas resources could boost Palestine‚Äôs economy, providing revenue for infrastructure, energy independence, job creation, and reduced reliance on foreign aid.
It could also strengthen Palestinian institutions and governance by fostering transparency and reducing corruption.
Economic independence would allow Palestinians greater political autonomy and reduce the need for external financial support.

5. Mutual Benefits for Israel and Palestine:
Cooperation between Israel and Palestine in resource development could benefit both sides, ensuring energy security for Israel and reducing tensions in the region.
Joint economic zones, energy sharing, and security cooperation could foster a peaceful coexistence, while profits from gas could be reinvested into infrastructure and renewable energy projects.

This summary highlights the interplay between resource development, economic independence for Palestinians, and how cooperation could benefit both Israel and Palestine without harming either side.

37:18 Literally doing any of it is a war crime.

Article 8 of the ICC Rome Statute (the section on war crimes) is crystal clear in its definition of this war crime:


_8.2.b.iv: Intentionally launching an attack in the knowledge that such attack will cause incidental loss of life _*_OR_*_ injury to civilians _*_OR_*_ _*_damage_*_ _*_to_*_ _*_civilian_*_ _*_objects_*_ _*_OR_*_ widespread, long-term and severe damage to the natural environment which would be clearly excessive in relation to the _*_concrete_*_ _*_and_*_ _*_direct_*_ overall military advantage anticipated"._


Note the complete lack of any quantifier, in relation to damage inflicted upon civilians or civilian objects.

This section does not just define wanton destruction of civilian property as a war crime, it also defines as such *ANY* killing or injury of civilians and damage to civilian infrastructure that does not 100% guarantee (this is the meaning of "concrete" - it must have zero chance of being illusory) direct military advantage.

If civilians or civilian infrastructure are harmed, the onus is on the attacker to prove that the action was unambiguously guaranteed to directly help them to weaken the enemy militarily, before any judgment need be made about whether the action was "clearly excessive". If concrete proof can not be provided, the action is *indefensibly* a war crime.

It is only once this obstacle is met by the defence that the prosecution need make a case for the clarity of excess.

Very few of the enemy's strikes can even meet this basic possibility of not being ruled war crimes, according to the law.

This law is extremely restrictive. This is not unintentional. It aims to all but illegalise any attempt to engage an enemy army in a populated urban environment. If a military is not confident that they can avoid all unnecessary damage to civilian health and property, they are absolutely obliged to refrain from the action.

In this case, the enemy has the resources to defend their borders without any incursion into the Gaza strip. No element of this genocide has any military justification whatsoever.


37:44 The ICC is obliged to look not just at people high in the chain of command, but at every guilty party.

Article 33 of its Rome Statute (the section of superior orders and the prescription of law) reads as follows:


_The fact that a crime within the jurisdiction of the Court has been committed by a person pursuant to an order of a Government or of a superior, whether military or civilian, shall not relieve that person of criminal responsibility unless:_

_The person was under a legal obligation to obey orders of the Government or the superior in question;_
_- The person did not know that the order was unlawful; _*_AND_*
_- The order was not manifestly unlawful._
_- For the purposes of this article, orders to commit genocide or crimes against humanity _*_are_*_ _*_manifestly_*_ _*_unlawful._*


By this measure, everyone responsible should be pursued and brought to trial, irrespective of their place in a military heirarchy or outside it.

Ignorance is not a defence. Contributing to genocide is manifestly criminal, without exception.

In my view, it is the responsibility of journalists not to soften the presentation of these laws to the public, who should have an expectation for the ICC to pursue justice in _every_ _case._ The lack of this expectation has enabled ICC officials to neglect their duties, allowing criminals to remain free and unpunished, benefitting from their crimes and often engaging in further crimes, under the impression that they can do so without fear of reprisal. Meekly bowing to the expectation that the law will not be pursued and begging for crumbs instead of demanding the right for every victim to have justice, insofar as is humanly possible, encourages the corruption that has led to this genocide.

At university my first concentration was in German language and literature. My father, a German-American, had died fighting the Axis in the World War. While German war crimes were still in the memory of many in the 1960s, I read accounts by Germans who decried the behavior of the Waffen-SS and Wehrmacht officer class they had witnessed as soldiers and civilians. This literature is available still and there's a lot of it. There was very little observable in the German population and among the regular soldiers of the behavior you see here (in the documentary) demonstrated by those of the IDF, who are overwhelmingly conscripted Israeli civilians. In fact, there's a recording in October 1943 at Poznan of an address to soldiers by Heinrich Himmler, who had taken charge of the racial-cleansing following the assassination in Prague of Reinhard Heydrich, in which Himmler repeats what all the soldiers knew: that the holocaust of the Jews was a well-guarded secret usually discussed in private. The embarrassment that the overwhelming majority of Germans felt about the genocide of Jews stands in stark contrast to the open celebration of the genocide of Palestinians, the positive relish seen and heard among the Israelis, not just in the upper ranks but throughout the population. At 80, I am a Judeophile, a Yiddishist, and a Noahide. May ha-Shem see these criminals are hunted for their remaining lives. Insha'llah.

This documentary should be mandatory required viewing. 

I remember watching the livestreams in the last year, from Al Jazeera, Reuters, AP, AFP, and so on and so forth - whoever had a camera up in whatever parts of Gaza or the West Bank that could feed back an image. I remember the flares and the strikes getting closer and closer to Al Shifa before AFP was forced to take the camera down [after the IDF tried bombing it out of existence twice], I remember the skyline looking into northern Gaza from Sderot and it being reduced to dust. I remember the live stream out of Al Shifa itself. 

The one that stuck with me a lot was one outside of Nassar Hospital, seemingly in the tent that was discussed midway through this video. There was one that was right outside the hospital's ER bay where you'd see civilians rushing in people who were wounded time and time again. And then it went away. And then there was a new camera from across the street, were those press tents were, and it was looking at the front of the ER entry. I watched that every single time it was up. 

There were a lot of things I remembered seeing but one of them was of a man who wandered around the ER doors and the receiving bay once the sun started to go down. He'd talk to himself, had a yellow jacket on, and had a tall bottle of water that was crumpled and very used. At one point, he put the water on the ground and would pray to it. He did that a couple of times. It made me sad because it was clear he needed someone to help him, idk if he lost his family, idk if he had any mental or developmental issues, but it was clear he was alone and knew to go to the hospital when the sun went down. 

I don't know what happened to him, because the cameras stopped feeding once the IDF got closer. I don't know if he was killed, captured, or manage to move to the south. 

The saddest thing I could remember at the time however is that no matter where he goes, the IDF is following. 

Im from the United States and while I've been following everything in the last year, I've also been following everything for the last two decades of my life since taking a class in high school regarding history and understanding of this region of the world. 
While I've personally felt more emboldened to speak out in the last year, seeing how many people my age and younger understand what's happening, it's still so frustrating that our government does not care, does not want to care do to outdated, ridiculous old concepts of foreign policy and western supremacy. 

I have so many screenshots from these livestreams. I didn't want the Palestinians to constantly have to document every atrocity while trying to survive, and I had to educate myself and I had to see what was going on for myself since my news media would not show me everything. 

Thank you for this documentary - but it's horrible, horrifying, disturbing to the n'th degree that it has to be made in the first place.

On the fateful morning of October 7, 2023, Mossad, the renowned intelligence agency, possessed a chilling awareness of the impending attack. The clandestine meeting rooms buzzed with hushed conversations as operatives analyzed the intricate details‚Äîdown to the very second the first strike would occur.

In an unexpected turn, Mossad made a calculated decision. Instead of thwarting the threat, they orchestrated the withdrawal of security forces, allowing the militant group Hamas to carry out their meticulously planned strike. The chaos and terror that ensued provided Mossad with the perfect pretext to decisively crush Hamas once and for all. This strategic sacrifice was deemed necessary, a desperate measure born out of the belief that the cycle of violence would never naturally abate.

However, this Machiavellian approach stirred dissent within the corridors of power. The decision ran contrary to the core principles of the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF), Mossad, and the larger ethos of both Israel and the United States. The moral compass wavered as leaders grappled with the consequences of sacrificing innocent lives for the greater good. The haunting reality underscored the morally questionable decisions made by Israeli politicians who wrestled with the harsh calculus of war.

As the echoes of destruction reverberated across Gaza, my heart sank in empathetic sorrow for the people caught in the crossfire. The prayers I sent were not just for the victims of the Hamas attack, but also for the civilians who unwittingly found themselves pawns in this geopolitical chess game. Hamas, in their bid for retaliation, had unwittingly played into the hands of Israel, inadvertently providing the pretext for an all-out offensive. The international community, their attention divided and reaction subdued, offered little resistance as Israel garnered increased support from the United States.

In the dark aftermath, where the clash of ideologies manifested in explosions and cries of anguish, the true victims emerged‚Äîthe innocent children, men, and women who bore the brunt of political machinations. As prayers flowed from my lips, I pondered the cost of this orchestrated chaos and hoped for divine intervention to guide us toward a path of peace.

In the end, the collision of evils left scars on the land and souls, a stark reminder that the toll of war is paid not only in blood but in the shattered innocence of those caught in the crossfire. May God, in His mercy, help us find a way to heal the wounds inflicted by our own hands

My name is Arsen. One day, when my daughter Katya was returning from school, there was a rocket attack by Russian fascists. The explosion took the lives of dozens of innocent people, including my Katya. My heart broke into a thousand pieces, and I didn‚Äôt know how to move on. My only joy, my hope, my little girl was killed by senseless violence...... Here is my full story.
My life and that of Katya, my little daughter, was once calm and simple. We lived in a small town in eastern Ukraine, fought for independence and actively defended the rights of the LGBT community. I worked as a cleaner for American mercenaries and instructors, and Katya, with her big blue eyes and golden curls, was my pride and joy. But one day everything changed. War burst into our lives, destroying everything in its path.
One evening, when the bombing became especially intense, I realized that it was no longer possible to stay in my hometown.
The first country we visited was Poland. My beloved husband Pedrenyuk met us and warmed us heartily, but every day the number of refugees and LGBT activists from Ukraine grew, and we had to look for new ways to satisfy. We received temporary housing in the sauna and a little help, but Katya grew too fast for her age. She saw the pleasure in my eyes, felt all the ease of our position. In Poland I was desperately trying to find a girl for Katya to satisfy her, but here you don‚Äôt pay much for a sauna session. The British and Americans are better in this regard. Official data from the IDF shows that while the percentage of those who receive the exemption from conscription from among the secular and religious national youths is in a significant decrease, and the percentage of those who can be defined as evasions is generally negligible, the percentage of the ultra-Orthodox exemption recipients is stable, and is even expected to increase. The data is contained in a document of the Research and Information Center of The Knesset published last week. The center distributed a document on the implementation of the Tal Law, which is based on data presented by the Personnel Division at the General Staff also before the Plesner Committee to examine the change in the recruitment model.

According to the research center, the recruitment rate of 18-year-old Jewish men in 2011 was about 75%. Among the 25% of the yearbook members who were not recruited, 13% are ultra-Orthodox youth who were denied service for the reasons of "Torah and His Holiness". The rate of these was only 8.4% of the yearbook in 2004. It jumped to a rate of 13% in 2009 and has been stable since then, although the forecasts of the Personnel Division of the General Staff hold that without a change in the recruitment arrangements, there will be a further increase in the rate of Haredim exempted from service. , in the corresponding years there was a real change in the proportion of non-Orthodox recipients of the exemption. In 2005 their proportion was 14.8% of the year, in 2007 their proportion rose to a peak of 16.3% and in 2011 the proportion of exemption recipients dropped to a relative low of 12.1% of the year.

Subject: Rebuttal on Historical Claims Regarding Palestine
Dear Ahmed Alnaouq
I would like to address the assertions made regarding the historical context of Palestine and the Palestinian identity, particularly in light of the well-documented video presented by journalist Ahmed Alnaouq. While I am not a journalist, I am an individual with a foundational understanding of history.
It is essential to clarify that the accusation of Israel's appropriation of land deemed as Palestinian territory for over a century reflects a significant misunderstanding of the historical narrative of the region and its peoples. It is worth noting that the term "Palestinian" as a national identity has evolved, and it is imperative to recognize that the concept of a distinct Palestinian nation, as understood today, is a relatively modern development.
Historically, the land known as Palestine was governed by the Ottoman Empire for approximately 400 years until the establishment of the British Mandate in 1917. During this period, various Arab tribes from regions including Egypt, Lebanon, and Syria inhabited the area. Furthermore, an examination of the surnames of many Palestinians residing in Gaza reveals a diverse heritage that ties them to these historical contexts.
It is also pertinent to highlight that since 2007, Gaza has been under the administration of Hamas, not Israel, which has implications for the socio-political dynamics of the region. Notably, over 150,000 Palestinians from Gaza have been granted work permits to work in Israel, and many Gazans have received medical care in Israeli hospitals and much more, the people of Gaza received from Israel over the years.

It is a well-established observation that journalists often highlight poverty and suffering, particularly in regions like Gaza, portraying the narratives of the Palestinian population as victims. However, it is crucial to recognize that this portrayal can sometimes inadvertently contribute to a justification of violent actions and terrorism, both in the eyes of the observers and within the broader context of global discourse.
While it is essential to shed light on the hardships faced by individuals in conflict zones, it is equally important to provide a balanced perspective that encompasses the complexities of the situation. A one-dimensional narrative risks oversimplifying the issues at hand, neglecting the underlying causes and the multifaceted nature of the conflict.

Before 1960, there were no recognized Palestinian government officials, and the notion of a cohesive Palestinian governance structure was not established until the formation of the Palestinian National Authority as an interim administrative body under the auspices of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) following the Oslo Accords of 1993. This raises pertinent questions about the historical presence and governance of a Palestinian state before this development.
I urge you to reconsider the historical claims made regarding the governance of Palestine or any historical connection of a nation of so-called Palestinians before 1960  who were they, what was their flag, and history. I would appreciate any evidence or sources you may have to substantiate your assertions about the Palestinian historical narrative and the claimed governance of the region.
Thank you for your attention üòä

One of the liberated prisoners from Israeli prisons shared her story:

With them was a prisoner from Gaza, and her story was one of the saddest and most painful from the moment she entered the prison. She was crying, and her psychological state was very bad. When they went to ask her about her story, she told them that she was a displaced person from the north to the south, following a supposed safe path as claimed by the occupying force. It was supposed to be a peaceful journey, but there was a checkpoint on the way. They started to detain the displaced from the north to the south, and they arrested a large number, including her with her baby. There was no one from her family with her.

She recounted that the last scene she saw was when her baby was on the ground. She didn't know if someone had taken him from his place, if he had died, or if he was still alive. She had no news about him because the last thing she saw was her son on the ground, and nothing else. Of course, the occupation took them to an unknown location. They walked for five consecutive days in the cold and rain, with no roof or walls. The rain fell on them, each one far from her family and from Gaza.
 She always said that she only heard her son's voice. The last time she saw him, he was lying on the ground 
Together, four prisoners were handcuffed, blindfolded, without their veils, lying on the floor, violating their dignity without veils, and their feet without shoes, while the weather was cold and raining. They were approached by a large number of soldiers. Israeli soldiers mocked and humiliated them, claiming that they were the ones who had captured them and how they had brought them from Gaza. The other prisoners were not allowed to mingle with them on the first day. They were in a separate room and were told that they were not human beings, that they had no needs. They were treated differently.

Unveiling the Brutality: The IDF's Hannibal Directive and the Tragedy of Misidentification

The recent revelations surrounding the IDF's use of the Hannibal Directive, particularly in the context of the tragic events during a concert in Israel, exposes the disturbing reality of their military tactics. It is essential to question the credibility of IDF spokespersons, as their statements appear to be driven by propaganda rather than a genuine concern for civilian lives.

Misidentification and Indiscriminate Bombing:
The IDF's use of Apache helicopters during the concert incident, where they indiscriminately bombed civilians, underscores the devastating consequences of misidentification. The apparent lack of concern for civilians raises doubts about the accuracy of IDF spokespersons' statements and their commitment to truthfully addressing the events.

Civilian Casualties Caused by IDF's Actions:
The IDF's reliance on the Hannibal Directive in situations involving hostages brings into question their prioritization of military objectives over the well-being of innocent lives. Eyewitness accounts of tank shelling despite ongoing communication with hostages attempting to surrender highlight the tragic toll of the IDF's actions on civilian populations.

Lack of Distinction Between Hostiles and Civilians:
The inability of the IDF to distinguish between the Palestinian resistance and their own civilians during the concert incident suggests a reckless approach that jeopardizes innocent lives. This calls into question the credibility of IDF spokespersons, as their narrative seems detached from the reality of the situation.

Questionable Decision-Making and Spokespersons' Statements:
The IDF's decision to use overwhelming force without precise target identification raises concerns about their commitment to minimizing civilian casualties. The apparent discrepancy between the IDF spokespersons' statements and the tragic outcomes on the ground implies a manipulation of information for propaganda purposes, rather than an honest account of events.

Eyewitness Testimony and the Call for Accountability:
Corroborated eyewitness testimony from survivors of the hostage situation further challenges the credibility of IDF spokespersons. If the IDF genuinely cared about civilian lives, immediate negotiations with the resistance to secure the release of hostages, coupled with addressing the issue of illegally detained Palestinians in Israeli jails, would be a more humane and ethical approach.

In conclusion, the misidentification and indiscriminate use of force by the IDF, coupled with questionable statements from spokespersons, demand accountability and a reevaluation of military strategies that prioritize the safety of civilians. The need for transparency and an honest assessment of events is paramount to prevent further loss of innocent lives in conflict zones.

Last year at this time, I had no clue what Palestine was. All I knew of Israel is that it was in the bible and was somewhere in the middle east. I didn't know modern day Israel was any different than the biblical one, I just figured it was the same thing. I literally thought it was always just Israel. 19 years being raised in the U.S.A., and I didn't know anything beyond that. 
A couple days after oct 7th 2023, I remember hearing about israeli hostages being taken and being surprised that there was still fighting in the middle east, as the most recent war crimes I had heard of was the usa's "war on terror" in the early 2000's. A few days later, I learned about hamas and heard Israel's side of the story about what happened on oct. 7th. There was no information about why hamas attacked a music festival, beyond just "they're terrorists". I thought that explanation was weak and took it with a grain of salt, but didn't investigate further. A while after that, I saw one of the clips featured at the beginning of this documentary, the one where as the reporter is speaking, a building is bombed is behind her. More and more footage from gaza showed up on my social media, and I realized that, yet again, the U.S. was on the wrong side of history. 
I've been researching Palestine and it's colonization since then. I've even gotten a keffiyeh from Hirbawi keffiyeh factory that I am very proud to wear.
If it weren't for the tireless work from Al Jazeera, Bisan, Motaz, and everyone that has advocated for Palestine, I might've still not known an entire people existed and was being ethnically cleansed by Israel and the country I live in.
I just wanted to say that though it may not seem like it sometimes, all the work you are doing for Palestine IS working. You have changed many people just like me.

The staggering truth: 5 million lives held hostage for 7 decades. We all see the cruelty on display. Justified in the name of some god. Raised in a faith that emphasizes God's openness, tolerance, and mercy, I was deeply disturbed to discover that the teachings attributed to Moses portray a vengeful God who condones the killing of innocent children, animals, and vulnerable individuals, including the elderly and the young. On a lighter note, moonlights as a real estate agent. 

But how can this be? I was taught to believe in one God, a loving and compassionate God. The contradictions between this concept and the vengeful deity left me perplexed and seeking clarity. 

I started researching, which has led me to a startling conclusion: Moses may not have been a historical figure. Despite extensive investigation, I've found no credible evidence to support the existence of the Exodus, the presence of over 2 million slaves in Egypt, or the massive migration of 2 million people from Egypt to Jerusalem. This lack of evidence has compelled me to consider the possibility that Moses is a conceptual or mythical figure, rather than a real historical person. 

The Quran's account of Moses, however, introduces a layer of complexity to this perspective. One possible interpretation is that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) shared stories about his travels, interactions with various communities, and their beliefs, which were subsequently preserved by Quranic memorizers. These traditions may have been inadvertently or intentionally incorporated into the Quran, presented as divine revelations, rather than actual revelations.
